docs.title: Welcome to the Les Paul Classic Website
docs.text:
Welcome to this website focused on the Les Paul Classic by Gibson, which is a contemporary take on the original Les Paul guitar from the 1960s. For those who are lucky enough to possess a Les Paul Classic, this website offers valuable insights and information. If you are an admirer of Gibson Les Paul guitars, I hope you will find the content presented here informative and engaging.

  • Inventory

    All the Les Paul Classic produced since 1989.

    Article

  • Les Paul Classic Antique

    Crown on the head, vintage-inspired.

    Article

  • Les Paul Classic Custom

    Classic with a taste of custom shop.

    Article

  • Les Paul Classic Guitars of the Week

    A unique guitar every week.

    Article

A Les Paul Classic 1960, the original model

docs.title: All The Guitars Of The Week (GOTW)
docs.text:
In 2007, Gibson did a series of limited editions called the Guitar Of The Week, also known as GOTW. A new limited run of 400 Guitars was presented every week on Tuesdays. The runs started on January 22nd with an SG Supreme Bass and finished on December 18th with a reissue of an RD Standard.

These limited editions brought a lot of different models on the market, with varying sets of features that were not common at this time. In some cases, like the Week 33, the old Gibson logo on the headstock can confuse and make you think the Guitar is fake. Reference: The "FANCY" Logo, 2007 Gibson Guitar of the Week 33 GOTW 33 Les Paul Classic Antique Review + Demo

Info

This website is dedicated to inventorying the different Les Paul Classic models. We will only detail the Les Paul Classic models and provide a list of all the other models that were part of the GOTW series.

  • 22 Les Paul
  • 13 SG
  • 5 Explorer
  • 3 Flying V
  • 3 Firebird
  • 1 RD

reference: See all of the Guitars of the Week

docs.title: Les Paul Classic Antique Guitar Of The Week #14
docs.text: The week 14 and its unique pickups.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
The Gibson Les Paul Classic Antique Guitar Of The Week #14, a part of the unique Guitar Of The Week event, is rare, with only 400 produced. This one-shot event, organized by Gibson in 2007, introduced a new and unique model every week alongside their regular production. We can compare the Guitar Of The Week to the current Mod Collection. On April 24th, in the 14th week, this Classic Antique was added to the list, the fourth Antique, following the regular, week#02, week#05. Three more models joined the family in weeks #19, #27, and #33, all in the same year, making it a limited and exclusive addition to any collection.

The Gibson Les Paul Classic Antique Guitar Of The Week #14 stands out among the several Les Paul Classics in Gibson's regular production. It inherits the iconic Les Paul Classic 1960s' and the Les Les Paul Classic Custom, but what truly sets it apart is its unique and exciting features, making it a must-have addition to any collection.

docs.title: Flamed Maple Top
docs.text:
The antiques are tributes to the iconic Les Paul Standard produced before it. This model has a flamed maple top and is wearing an iced tea burst. The colour of an Ice Tea Burst Les Paul guitar can be described as a warm, sun-kissed gradient that combines shades of amber, honey, and deep tea brown. The center of the guitar typically showcases a lighter, golden amber hue, which gradually transitions into darker brown tones towards the edges, resembling the colour of iced tea. The top can vary from a calm, subtle dancing top to a stripped, apparent flame one. The back is the same colour as the edge of the top.

The model is not advertised as weight-relieved, but it is expected to be under 8 lbs, which is low for a Les Paul. It is associated with high-quality wood that was used at this time. The lightweight keeps a great sound and sustain, as expected from a Les Paul.

docs.title: Royal Headstock
docs.text:
The antiques share the same kind of headstock. Unlike regular Classics, the head is enlightened with vintage bindings, continuing the neck decoration. In the middle of the headstock, the Les Paul silk screen is replaced by the holy crown, which you would find on SG or ES models.

Headstock, with the Holy Crown

docs.title: Slim taper Neck
docs.text: The Les Paul Classics are well known for their neck—a modern profile replicating the 1960 Les Paul "Burst". It is the slimmer neck from Gibson's production. The first fret is commonly around 0.8 to 0.9 inches, and the 12th fret is close to 1.00 inches but rarely more. The rosewood fingerboard is decorated with vintage bindings and pearloid trapezoid inlays.

docs.title: Unique pickups
docs.text:
The Week#14 model had a unique AA flamed maple ice tea burst. One of the key differences from the regular production is the pickups. At first sight, they can be seen as P-90, which would be already something noticeable for a Les Paul Classic. However, what appears as P-90s are H-90 pickups: 'Humbuckers'-90. These are not traditional P-90s but a particular type of pickup developed by Gibson in collaboration with Billie Joe Armstrong. The H-90 offers the snarl and punch of a classic, vintage P-90 with no 60-cycle hum that usually plagues traditional single-coil pickups. H-90 pickups are stacked magnets on top of each other, while regular humbuckers are side-by-side magnets.

Additionally, the H-90 offers a split to mimic the sound of regular P-90s. The two-tone controls are push/pull. Only this model, week#14, was equipped with these H-90s; this is the first Gibson model to have them since.

docs.title: Luxury Hardware
docs.text:
The regular antique nickel hardware is replaced here by luxurious golden hardware. The tune-o-matic, the stop bar and the strap buttons are upgraded, giving a regal aspect to the guitar. The knobs are ambered speed knobs. Green key pearloid in the gold finish is again a tribute to the Les Paul Standards.

All these upgrades, combined with the iced tea flame top, give the guitar an elegant and impressive appearance.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Specifications

BODYNECKFINGERBOARDHARDWAREELECTRONICS
  • Top Species: AA Figured Maple
  • Back Species: Mahogany

  • Finishes: Ice Tea Burst
  • Species: Mahogany

  • Head Inlay: Antique Binding, Holly Crown

  • Species: Rosewood

  • Plating Finish: Gold
  • Tailpiece: Stopbar
  • Bridge: Tune-O-Matic

docs.title: The Classic Antique Family
docs.text:
Headstock of a Les Paul Classic Antique, first edition

In 2007, Gibson produced The Les Paul Antique and the Les Paul Classic Custom, two unique series of the well-known Les Paul Classic. The Les Paul Classic Antique has a flamed maple top, a crown on the headstock, and an aged binding on the body and neck. The Les Paul Classic Antique was produced between 2007 and 2008. In 2007, Gibson produced several limited runs during the Guitar Of The Week event. All the Antique come initially with a Hardshell With a Black Reptile Pattern with a white interior.

docs.title: Flamed Maple Top
docs.text:
The antiques are tributes to the iconic Les Paul Standard produced before it. The model has a flamed maple top and is available in three finishes: Honeyburst, Heritage Cherry Sunburst, and Vintage Sunburst. The top can vary from a calm, subtle dancing top to a stripped, apparent flame one.

The model is not advertised as weight-relieved, but it is expected to be under 8 lbs, which is low for a Les Paul. It is associated with high-quality wood that was used at this time. The lightweight keeps a great sound and sustain, as expected from a Les Paul.

docs.title: Slim taper Neck
docs.text: The Les Paul Classics are well known for their neck—a modern profile replicating the 1960 Les Paul "Burst". It is the slimmer neck from Gibson's production. The first fret is commonly around 0.8 to 0.9 inches, and the 12th fret is close to 1.00 inches but rarely more. The rosewood fingerboard is decorated with vintage bindings and pearloid trapezoid inlays.

docs.title: Royal Headstock
docs.text:
Unlike regular Classics, the head is enlightened with vintage bindings, continuing the neck decoration. The Les Paul silk screen is replaced in the middle of the headstock by the holy crown found on SG or ES models.

Headstock, with the Holy Crown

docs.title: Aged bindings
docs.text:
The antique refers to an aged guitar that comes from the past. The binding on the body and the neck has a yellow tint to mimic what happens to the binding over time. The light tints the varnish on vintage guitars over the years. The lacquer turns yellow. It is more evident in the biding as it is white or cream. However, the entire guitar is affected by aging. On the Antique, the aging effect is only applied to the binding.

On the left is a natural binding on a current Les Paul Classic. On the right, aged binding on antique on a GOTW#14. On the top is a typical headstock of a Les Paul Classic. On the bottom is the crowned headstock of a Les Paul Classic Antique.

docs.title: Aged bindings
docs.text: The antique refers to an aged guitar that comes from the past. The binding on the body and the neck has a yellow tint to mimic what happens to the binding over time. The light has tinted the lacquer on vintage guitars over the years. The lacquer turns yellow. It is more evident in the biding as it is white or cream. However, the entire guitar is affected by aging. On the Antique, the aging effect is only applied to the binding.

docs.title: Inventory of the Les Paul Classic Antique
docs.text:
The Les Paul Classic Antique was produced in 2007 and 2008. It only exists in one regular edition and six limited editions, part of the Guitar of the Week series.

Inventory of the Les Paul Classic Antique (click to expand) photo model starting ending link Les Paul Classic Antique 2007 2008 Specs reverb Week 02 - Les Paul Classic Antique - fireburst 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 05 - Les Paul Classic Antique Artist Series 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 14 - Les Paul Classic Antique - H90 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 19 - Les Paul Classic Antique - Zebra 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 27 - Les Paul Classic Antique - Faded Cherry 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 33 - Les Paul Classic Antique - Mahogany Top 2007 2007 Specs reverb

docs.title: The Regular Edition
docs.text:
The regular edition of the Les Paul Classic Antique is a vintage-inspired guitar. It comes with an AA maple top, a mahogany body, and a mahogany neck with a gloss finish. It is loaded with two '57 Classic humbuckers.

It comes in three different finishes: Honey burst, Heritage Cherry Sunburst , and Vintage Sunburst.

A Les Paul Classic Antique in Honey Burst. Specifications (click to expand) BODYNECKFINGERBOARDHARDWAREELECTRONICS

  • Tailpiece: Stopbar
  • Bridge: Tune-O-Matic

  • Bridge Pickup: '57 Classic Plus, Uncovered With Nickel Polepieces

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week 02 - Les Paul Classic Antique - fireburst
docs.text:
The Week 2 - Les Paul Classic Antique, released on January 29th, 2007, is a Les Paul Classic Antique, including a figured maple top and a pair of Gibson's '57 Classic humbuckers—with an exceptional Fireburst finish. The finish is also called "lava burst" and featured on the CG Supreme of 2000 - 2007.

The fireburst finish of the Les Paul Classic Antique week 02. source: Audiofanzine Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODY
  • Finishes: Fireburst

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week 05 - Les Paul Classic Antique Artist Series
docs.text:
It is another Les Paul Classic Antique. This Guitar has a unique finish, made and signed by Tom Morgan. The finishing is sometimes called Tom Morgan Lava. The back is painted black.

The unique body of the Les Paul Classic Antique week 05. source: fusionmusic Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODY
  • Finishes: Tom Morgan Art

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week 14 - Les Paul Classic Antique - H90
docs.text:
The Gibson Les Paul Classic Antique Guitar Of The Week #14, a part of the unique Guitar Of The Week event, is rare, with only 400 produced. This one-shot event, organized by Gibson in 2007, introduced a new and unique model every week alongside their regular production. We can compare the Guitar Of The Week to the current Mod Collection. On April 24th, in the 14th week, this Classic Antique was added to the list, the fourth Antique, following the regular, week#02, week#05. Three more models joined the family in weeks #19, #27, and #33, all in the same year, making it a limited and exclusive addition to any collection.

The Gibson Les Paul Classic Antique Guitar Of The Week #14 stands out among the several Les Paul Classics in Gibson's regular production. It inherits the iconic Les Paul Classic 1960s' and the Les Les Paul Classic Custom, but what truly sets it apart is its unique and exciting features, making it a must-have addition to any collection.

The week 14 and its unique H-90 pickups. Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODYHARDWAREELECTRONICS
  • Finishes: Ice Tea Burst
  • Plating Finish: Gold
  • Neck Pickup: H-90
  • Bridge Pickup: H-90
  • Controls: 2 volume, 2 tone, 3-way switch - with push/pull pots

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week 19 - Les Paul Classic Antique - Zebra
docs.text:
The week 19 offers a unique Zebrawood top without binding. This unique wood is known for its striking appearance and gives the guitar a rough and wild look. Mind that the tops have different waves and lines and can differ significantly from one guitar to another. It can be hard to evaluate the quality of the wood from a picture. The finish is a natural satin.

The guitar is packed with two Burstbucker Pro humbuckers in neck and bridge positions.

The unique body of the Les Paul Classic Antique week 19. source: Lovies Guitars Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODYELECTRONICS
  • Top Species: Zebrawood
  • Binding: None
  • Finishes: Natural Satin
  • Neck Pickup: Burstbucker Pro humbuckers
  • Bridge Pickup: Burstbucker Pro humbuckers

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week 27 - Les Paul Classic Antique - Faded Cherry
docs.text:
The Week 27's Les Paul Classic Antique continues Gibson's Classic line with vintage touches. The mahogany top is finished in Faded Cherry. The pickups are '57 Classic PAF humbuckers.

A Les Paul Classic Antique in Faded Cherry, the Guitar Of The Week #27. Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODY
  • Top Species: Mahogany
  • Finishes: Faded Cherry

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Guitar Of The Week #33, Les Paul Classic Antique - Mahogany Top
docs.text:
It is easy to confuse the regular edition of the Antique with The Guitar of The Week #33. They are both in a vintage sunburst with chrome hardware. However, the distinct details make week #33 different from its sister.

The headstock of the limited edition has a pre-war Gibson logo. The crown and the binding are not present on the headstock. The regular Les Paul Model silk screen replaces the crown.

The finish is also something to pay attention to. The limited edition has a smooth satin finish instead of a gloss finish. Finally, the vintage sunburst is darker in this model.

The satin finish of week #33 is visible on the body. source: Trogly's Guitar Show Unique Specifications (click to expand)

On top of the specification of the regular model, the week #33 has the following unique features:

BODYNECK
  • Top Species: Mahogany
  • Body Finish: Satin Nitrocellulose Lacquer
  • Finishes: Satin Vintage Sunburst
  • Head Inlay: Americana "Gibson" Script
  • Head Binding: None

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: External links
docs.text: • The "FANCY" Logo, 2007 Gibson Guitar of the Week 33 GOTW 33 Les Paul Classic Antique Review + Demo

docs.title: The Classic Customs
docs.text:
Head of a first edition Les Paul Classic Custom

In 2007, Gibson, along with the Les Paul Classic Antique, released the first version of the Les Paul Classic Custom. The guitar was a mix of the legendary Les Paul Custom and the Les Paul Classic, with a mahogany body and neck, a maple top, and a rosewood fingerboard.

In 2007, the Les Paul Classic Custom was also part of the Guitar Of The Week series. Followed by several additional runs from 2011 to 2012 and then in 2014, with different specs. No Classic Custom were produced after 2014.

The Classic Custom shares the same distinct features as her sister: the crown inlay on the headstock and the aged binding.

On the top, the headtock of a Classic Custom 2007. On the bottom, the headstock of a Classic Antique 2007.

All the Classic Customs have a common attribute. They are all close to a model the Gibson Les Paul Custom Shop produced. Many of them mimic the fantastic Black Beauty with an ebony finish. That's the reason why they wear 7-ply binding clothes. They look to be tributes to the original Les Paul Custom Black Beauty. The first Classic Custom from 2007 can be seen as a tribute the 1957's Les Paul Custom. The guitar also had a brass truss rod cover with the words Les Paul engraved on it.

docs.title: A tribute to the Les Paul Custom
docs.text:
Although Classic Custom guitars looked similar to the Les Paul Custom, some differences could be spotted by a keen eye.

For instance, the first difference was in the fretboard inlays. While the Black Beauty had block inlays, Classic Custom had trapezoid inlays. Moreover, the first case of the neck was not inlaid, unlike the Black Beauty.

The Classic Custom guitar had a slim taper neck, while the Black Beauty had a 50's medium C.

The headstock was another point of differentiation. It had a crown inlay, while the Les Paul Custom had a split diamond inlay. Exception for the edition 2011-2012, which out on a split-diamond inlay.

The back of the guitar was also different. The 7-ply binding was only on the top of the body, whereas the back was not bound. In contrast, the Black Beauty had a 7-ply binding on both the top and the back.

The back of a Classic Custom 2012 without the binding. source: The Twelfth Fret

docs.title: Inventory of the Les Paul Classic Custom
docs.text:
The first Les Paul Classic Custom was produced in 2007 and 2008. In 2007, during the Guitar of the Week series, five different versions of the Les Paul Classic Custom were produced, each with unique features.

The Les Paul Classic Custom was also produced in 2011, 2012, and 2014.

Inventory of the Les Paul Classic Custom (click to expand) photo model starting ending link Les Paul Classic Custom 2007 2012 Specs reverb Week 16 - Les Paul Classic Custom Silverburst 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 28 - Les Paul Classic Custom 2 P-90 Pickups 2007 2007 Specs Week 39 - Les Paul Classic Custom - creme 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 42 - Les Paul Classic Custom w/3 Pickups - heritage cherry burst 2007 2007 Specs reverb Week 46 - Les Paul Classic Custom w/3 Pickups 2007 2007 Specs reverb Les Paul Classic Custom 2011-2012 2011 2012 Specs reverb Les Paul Classic Custom Lite 2014 2014 Specs reverb

docs.title: Les Paul Classic Custom 2007-2008
docs.text:
The guitar has a pair of unique gold-appointed '57 Classic humbuckers and a slim-taper neck. This version was only available in a black ebony finish, with an aged binding and gold hardware, making it look like a Black beauty from the 50s.

The first edition, only available in a black ebony finish, was produced between 2007 and 2008, with only 150 to 200 copies, making it one of the rarest Les Paul Classic models ever produced by Gibson.

All these assets make the Les Paul Classic Custom a desirable guitar for collectors.

The crowned headstock of a Les Paul Classic Custom. Specifications (click to expand) BODYNECKFINGERBOARDHARDWAREELECTRONICS

  • Back Species: Mahogany

docs.title: Week 28 - Les Paul Classic Custom 2 P-90 Pickups
docs.text:
For week 28, Gibson released a special edition Les Paul Classic Custom with two P-90 pickups. The guitar was available only in a black ebony finish, with an aged binding and gold hardware, which gave it a look similar to a Les Paul Custom from 1954.

The main difference between week 28 and the original Classic Custom was the pickups. Week 28 featured P-90s instead of humbuckers.

docs.title: A tribute to the 1954's Black Beauty
docs.text:
The two P-90 pickups on the guitar makes it a tribute to the 1954 Black Beauty. Note, the original Black Beauty had an alnico V "staple" pickup in the neck position and a P-90 in the bridge position.

A close up of the pickups of the week 28. source: Guitar Lovers Unique Specifications (click to expand) ELECTRONICS
  • Neck Pickup: P-90
  • Bridge Pickup: P-90

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Week 39 - Les Paul Classic Custom - creme
docs.text:
Unlike most of the other Classic Custom models, the week 39 edition was only available in a creme finish. The guitar trades the aged bindings for white bindings. Gold covers hide the '57 Classic humbuckers.

Pictures of the headstock and the creme body of the week 39. source: Reverb Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODYHARDWAREELECTRONICS
  • Finishes: Creme
  • Knobs: Gold Speed Knobs
  • Neck Pickup: Gold Covered '57 Classic Humbucker
  • Bridge Pickup: Gold Covered '57 Classic Humbucker

reference: Gibson.com

docs.title: Les Paul Classic Custom 2014
docs.text:
In 2014, Gibson released a limited edition of the Classic Custom of 400 copies for Guitar Center. This limited edition had a unique headstock with a flower pot inlay. The flower pot was a tribute to the early Gibson models. The model featured the same specs as the 2011-2012 edition.

Unique headstock with flower pot of the limited edition Classic Custom 2014. source: Reddit Unique Specifications (click to expand)

docs.text:
Unique Specifications (click to expand) BODYNECKFINGERBOARDHARDWAREELECTRONICS

docs.title: Inventory of the Les Paul Classics
docs.text:
Several different bodies of the Les Paul Classic.

Since the first year of production, in 1989, the Les Paul Classic has been a popular model. The Les Paul Classic has been produced in different versions, and each one has its own unique features. And we are documenting them all.

Each Les Paul Classic can be seen a tribute to a iconic Les Paul guitar. The first Les Paul Classic, the 1960, was a tribute to the 1960 Les Paul Standard.

In 2018, a version with two P90 pickups was released. It was produced with a gold top finish and an ebony finish, tribute to the Les Paul of 1956.

A 2018 Les Paul Classic with P90 pickups Goldtop (left) and a 1956 Les Paul Goldtop (right) side by side.

The listing include the model, a picture of one of the finishes, the year the production started, and the year it ended. The links are to the dedicated pages for each model and the Reverb page for the model.
